dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so we're talking about Guild Education today, right? This company that's helping businesses, um, boost retention by offering degrees and stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so we're talking about Guild Education today, right? This company that's helping businesses, um, boost retention by offering degrees and stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's why many of the nation's largest companies, from Lowe's to Taco Bell, have turned to Denver-based Guild Education to help them retain employees through offering pathways to high school and college degrees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! Like, Taco Bell, surprisingly not based in Denver, by the way, but they're using Guild. And Rachel Carlson, the CEO, she was at the Forbes Women's Summit, saying that when companies invest in their frontline workers, it actually leads to, like, way higher retention, better recruitment, all that good stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! Like, Taco Bell, surprisingly not based in Denver, by the way, but they're using Guild. And Rachel Carlson, the C E O, she was at the Forbes Women's Summit, saying that when companies invest in their frontline workers, it actually leads to, like, way higher retention, better recruitment, all that good stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over the last number of years weve proven that when companies invest in their frontline workforce they become more attractive for people to work at the company and stay at the company [with] higher retention rates, higher recruitment rates, higher up-scaling rates and a more positive brand as a corporate company in America, Guild cofounder and CEO Rachel Carlson said at the Forbes Women's Summit last week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm, interesting. So it's not just about, like, big corporate execs, right? Guild's really focusing on those frontline and low-income workers, which is, uh, a huge group â€“ like 64 million people.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm, interesting. So it's not just about, like, big corporate execs, right? Guild's really focusing on those frontline and low-income workers, which is, uh, a huge group - like sixty four million people.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While many corporate education programs focus on white collar workers, Guild estimates that 64 million frontline and low-income workers will need further education in order to compete in an increasingly automated world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Think cashiers, customer service reps, restaurant staff. And you see programs like Walmart's Live Better U, where employees only pay a dollar a day for tuition. It's, like, incredible.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Think cashiers, customer service reps, restaurant staff. And you see programs like Walmart's Live Better U, where employees only pay a dollar a day for tuition. It's, like, incredible.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, the nation's largest employer Walmart's Live Better U program covers all tuition costs after financial aid, with the employee contributing only $1 a day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But then you have someone like Stephanie Ruhle from MSNBC, who's a bit more, uh, skeptical.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you have someone like Stephanie Ruhle from M S N B C, who's a bit more, uh, skeptical.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet not everyone is convinced. When you listen to any analyst call, Ive never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing,countered Ruhle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, she was like, "When do you ever hear an analyst ask about the 'good' a company is doing?" Right? It's all about the numbers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, she was like, When do you ever hear an analyst ask about the good a company is doing? Right? It's all about the numbers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When you listen to any analyst call, Ive never heard an analyst ask about the good a company is doing,countered Ruhle.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And Carlson actually, um, kind of agreed with that, in a way. She said almost every CEO they work with sees sending employees back to school as a "hidden cost" in their earnings calls.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And Carlson actually, um, kind of agreed with that, in a way. She said almost every C E O they work with sees sending employees back to school as a hidden cost in their earnings calls.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carlson says it's because nearly every CEO they work with has mentioned sending their employees back to school as something 'good' in their earnings call. It wasnt them just giving themselves a pat on the back it had lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment, she explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which, like, affects their profits, recruitment, and retention, apparently. So it's not just a pat on the back, it's a genuine impact on the bottom line.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, like, affects their profits, recruitment, and retention, apparently. So it's not just a pat on the back, it's a genuine impact on the bottom line.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It wasnt them just giving themselves a pat on the back it had lifted their profits, recruitment and retainment, she explained.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. Still, Guild's doing pretty well, though, pulling in like $70 million in funding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. Still, Guild's doing pretty well, though, pulling in like seventy million dollars in funding.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In addition to serving 3 million employees, the company has attracted over $70 million in funding from firms like Bessemer Venture Partners, Cowboy Ventures and Silicon Valley Bank.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. But here's an interesting twist: the gig economy. Companies like Lyft are clients, but their drivers are actually paying tuition. No perks there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. But here's an interesting twist: the gig economy. Companies like Lyft are clients, but their drivers are actually paying tuition. No perks there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though Lyft is currently a client offering some educational perks, drivers are not able to receive tuition reimbursement the way other employees might.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. So, like, gig workers aren't getting the same educational benefits as, say, a Taco Bell employee?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. So, like, gig workers aren't getting the same educational benefits as, say, a Taco Bell employee?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though Lyft is currently a client offering some educational perks, drivers are not able to receive tuition reimbursement the way other employees might.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Nope. And it's because the tax code, surprisingly, allows for non-taxable education assistance for *some* workers, but not gig workers in the same way. So Guild is, like, lobbying to change that tax incentive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope. And it's because the tax code, surprisingly, allows for non-taxable education assistance for some workers, but not gig workers in the same way. So Guild is, like, lobbying to change that tax incentive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's because the tax code doesn't allow companies to provide nontaxable education assistance to those workers. Lobbying to change this tax incentive might be the company's greatest hurdle yet.

dialogue_turns.text: So that could be a huge play for them then, um, if they can get that through.
